audio_description: Greetings from Mulakkam Welcome to Tooty’s Kitchen Chennai. Today we’re going to see a very, very famous Dindigul-style Thalappakatti Mutton Biryani. We’ll make it just like how it’s served at the restaurant—guaranteed to get that authentic taste.

audio_description: Now we’re going to grind a special masala. For that, take 100g of shallots. Shallots are a must for this. Then take 50g of garlic and 50g of ginger. Also, take some green chilies depending on your spice level.

audio_description: Add 8 cloves, 8 cardamoms, just 1 star anise, a small piece of mace, and a small piece of nutmeg. If you have nutmeg powder, that’s fine too. Just use a little bit.

audio_description: Now grind everything into a fine powder. No need to dry roast anything—just grind directly. For the mutton, we’ve taken 700g. For half a kilo of rice, use about half a kilo of mutton. You can use a bit more if you like.

audio_description: Add enough water for the mutton to cook. Then add 2 teaspoons of salt. Mix everything well, pressure cook it for about 4-5 whistles until the mutton is nicely cooked. While that’s cooking, we’ll grind the masala.

audio_description: When grinding, don’t add too much water. Just a little is enough to make a coarse paste—not too fine. It should look like this. Now let’s grind the garam masala as well. The aroma is so good even while grinding.

audio_description: Now roast the mutton in the oil for a few minutes until it slightly changes color. Then add chopped mint and coriander leaves. Roast this together for a few minutes as well.

audio_description: Once the mutton is well roasted, add the masala powders: 1 tbsp chili powder, 1 tbsp coriander powder, and ½ tbsp cumin powder. Sauté until the raw smell goes away.

audio_description: Now it looks perfect. At this stage, squeeze in the juice of one lemon. For cooking the rice, measure 2 cups of water for every 1 cup of rice. I’ve used part of the water from the mutton broth and the rest as fresh water.

audio_description: Personally, I feel seeraga samba rice works better than basmati for this. It cooks faster too. So always use the 1:2 rice-to-water ratio. If not, the rice won’t cook uniformly and might remain a bit hard.

audio_description: Now close the lid and place a dosa tawa under the pan. Let it go on "dum" for 15 minutes—first 5 minutes on high flame, and the remaining 10 minutes on low flame.

audio_description: This biryani is much easier to make than other types and can be done quickly. Honestly, it turned out really well. Try it out and let me know how it came out. I hope all of you love this recipe. If you do, give us a thumbs up!
